ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

Via Devographics

The Results of State of HTML 2023 â€” You may recall late last year we shared the very first â€˜State of HTMLâ€™ survey â€”Â from the same folks behind the excellent JavaScript and CSS efforts. Well, now we have the results from that 2023 questionnaire. Lots of interesting tidbits here, including thoughts on recent HTML features, adoption, accessibility, extensibility, and much more.

ğŸ’¬ â€œSome argue that improving HTML is futile, but the survey resoundingly demonstrates the contrary. Developers crave more interactive HTMLÂ elements.â€
â€”Â Lea Verou

Make the Most of Your Design System with StackBlitz â€” We know thereâ€™s no shortage of challenges when building and maintaining enterprise design systems. StackBlitz helps you make the most of yours by improving developer experience, driving adoption, increasing bug reporting efficiency, and simplifyingÂ collaboration.

StackBlitz sponsor

10 Updates from Google I/O 2024: Unlocking the Power of AI for Every Web Developer â€” Googleâ€™s annual developer conference got underway yesterday, and we already have a handful of headlines for those of us working on the web â€”Â this post outlines 10 features that Google are keen to put the spotlight on, including (to no surprise) lots of AI additions. â–¶ï¸ Here's the developer keynote if you want to watch. Weâ€™ll share more, including session videos, as theyÂ drop.

Paul Kinlan

Announcing the Web Platform Dashboard â€” The â€˜Web Platform Dashboardâ€™, announced at Google I/O, is a new, easy way to see a high-level overview of the entire web platform mapped out as a set of features, along with their respective browserÂ support.

Rachel Andrew (Chrome)

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ§® All major browser engines now support the CSS stepped value math functions â€” that's round(), mod(), and rem().

  • ğŸ§­ Version 17.5 of Safari is out now, with seven new features (including text-wrap: balance, and the light-dark() color function) along with 22 bug fixes.

  • ğŸ”“ The Screen Wake Lock API (which lets you control a device's screen wake behavior) has now landed in Chrome, Safari and Firefox.

  • âœ¨ Here's what's new in Chrome 125, including anchor positioning (more on that below), the storage access API, and more.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Introducing the CSS Anchor Positioning API â€” With anchor positioning built into the browser, youâ€™ll be able to build layered user interfaces without relying on third-party libraries â€”Â itâ€™s in Chrome as of versionÂ 125.

Una Kravets

The Times You Need a Custom @property Instead of a CSSÂ Variable â€” Demonstrates where custom properties may be a more suitable option over variables, and showcases some of the freedom and flexibility that custom properties affordÂ us.

Preethi Sam

Your Background Images Might Be Causing CLS by Salma Alamâ€‘Naylor â€” In this post, learn how to to avoid unexpected cumulative layout shift (CLS) with tried and testedÂ solutions.

Sentry sponsor

The Modern Guide for Making CSS Shapes â€” A comprehensive guide with modern techniques for creating common shapes with the smallest and most flexible CSS codeÂ possible.

Temani Afif

Iâ€™m Worried About the Tabbing Behavior, Rather than the Syntax and Name of 'CSS Masonry' â€” Some more thoughts on the recent CSS Masonry debate, with Andy noting that we should â€œworry about the basicsÂ firstâ€.

Andy Bell

Hardest Problem in Computer Science: Centering Things â€” â€œEven if itâ€™s hard. Even if tools make it inconvenient. Even if you have to search for solutions. Together, I trust, we can find our way back to putting one rectangle inside another rectangle without messing itÂ up.â€

Niki Tonsky

Manifesto for a Humane Web â€” In an age of trackers, bots, and generative AI, Michelle makes the case for a web by and forÂ humans.

Michelle Barker

Five Basic Things About JavaScript That Will Help Non JavaScript-FocusedÂ WebÂ Designers
Chris Coyier

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

WordPress Studio: A Local App for Running WordPress in Dev â€” There have long been unofficial ways to run WordPress on your local machine to make life easier as you set things up, design themes, etc. but now WordPress has an official, quick, lightweight, and shareable local WordPress dev environment. For Mac so far, with Windows in â€˜earlyÂ access.â€™

WordPress

Adding Customizable Network Visualization Capabilities to YourÂ Apps â€” Find out how JS libraries can help you build rich network visualizations in your apps that are interactive &Â insightful.

Linkurious sponsor

DOM Projects: A Collection of Projects to Learn Frontend Development â€” Mainly for beginners, this serves as inspiration for learning to build simple apps with JS and DOM manipulation. Choose a project to view the source and try to build the same appÂ yourself.

Jisan Mia Beginner

WyW-in-JS: A Toolkit for Zero-Runtime CSS-in-JS Libraries â€” Meaning â€œWhatever-you-want-in-JSâ€, it allows developers to build their own CSS-in-JS solution thatâ€™s decoupled from any specific implementation. As an example, Material UIâ€™s Pigment CSS is based on thisÂ tool.

Anton Evzhakov

ğŸ¨Â Color Picker: Pick Colors by Clicking on Any Image â€” Upload an image then use an eyedropper tool to select pixels one at a time to generate a color palette. You can also save palettes and choose the output format (RGB, Hex, HSL). Easier than installing a local tool,Â perhaps.

Rayid Ashraf

go-masonry-gallery: A CLI Tool to Generate a Simple HTML/CSS Masonry Gallery from a Local Folder â€” Note that the generated result makes use of the recently debated, still experimental Masonry feature for CSS gridÂ layout.

Dominick Peluso

An Alternative Proposal for CSS Masonry â€” Last week we shared WebKitâ€™s thoughts on how to approach creating masonry type layouts in CSS. Now the Chrome team has weighed in, stating that â€œimplementing it as part of the CSS Grid specification [..] would be a mistakeâ€, and they think it should be its own separate layout method defined using display: masonry or somethingÂ similar.

Rachel Andrew (Chrome)

ğŸ¤” Kevin Powell has shared his thoughts over on his channel, highlighting the broader layout disagreement at play here. Plus, Chris Coyier has penned some feedback too.

Here's a Simple Video API for Your Next.js Application â€” Integrate a video player into your Next.js applications! Learn about HTML5 video tag, video.js library, and how you can unlock more functionality and performance with the ImageKit Video API. Deliver an optimized, buffer-free video stream everyÂ time.

ImageKit sponsor

The Popover API is Here â€” The Popover API now has broad support, and as such Chris gives us a brief overview of how it differs from <dialog> and how we may want to approach usingÂ it.

Chris Coyier

Lots of good examples here and a reminder of just how far you can takeÂ CSS!

Stephen Band

Ahmad Shadeed

Reaction-Diffusion Compute Shader in WebGPU â€” A look at how to use WebGPU compute shaders to create some rather wild looking patterns. Support is limited right now, but itâ€™s a neatÂ effect.

Robert Leitl

William Brown

The Intl.Segmenter Object is Now Part of Baseline â€” For interoperable, locale-sensitive textÂ segmentation.
Rachel Andrew

DesignSystemHunt

Cezar Augusto

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” "Compared to our previous experiences in the security/auth space, Userfront is an order of magnitude simpler toÂ use."

Userfront sponsor

Popicons: A Set of Free Figma/SVG Icons in Line, Solid & Duotone Styles â€” Designed in Figma and you can download the whole lot or go directly to the searchable gallery and copy the SVG codeÂ directly.

Popicons

Only <Spans>: Each Element on This Page is a SPAN â€” A silly what-not-to-do experiment that demonstrates the fact that every element on a page can be an HTML <span> element but modified for different roles usingÂ CSS.

OnlySpans

Fluid for Tailwind CSS â€” A fluid clamp() plugin for Tailwind that works with every utility. RepoÂ here.

Maxwell Barvian

JSON Generator: An Intuitive Tool for Crafting Complex JSON Structures â€” Includes 40+ â€œtemplate tagsâ€ (or functions) that you can incorporate into the JSON template so you can generate specific types of content for use in testing, mocking, teaching, and soÂ on.

JSON Generator

'Doom' Scroll â€” A neat demo of @scroll-timeline â€”Â a new CSS property that allows animations to be driven by a containerâ€™s scroll position. YMMV on browser support here.

Adam Kuhn
